subsection_content:
Dementia is a syndrome of deterioration in memory, thinking, behavior and the ability to perform daily activities. This disease not only has a negative impact on the physical, psychosocial and economic well-being of people with dementia, but also on their caregivers.
Although dementia mainly affects older people, it is not a normal aging process but is also the result of a number of disease factors. Alzheimer's disease is the most common form of dementia and may account for 60-70% of cases.
In addition, risk factors for dementia can also be obesity and high blood pressure in middle age; low blood pressure in the elderly; diabetes; multifocal cerebral infarction; increase blood fat; habit of drinking alcohol and/or using stimulants; family history of dementia; depression…
